channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: President Trump Criticizes Stimulus Package in Twitter Video
item.description: Zoom out: We don’t know yet whether President Trump will derail the bill. That wasn’t enough for Trump  The president said, “I am asking Congress to amend this bill and increase the ridiculously low $600 to $2,000, or $4,000 for a couple.”
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: USPS Hit by Triple Whammy of Challenges Ahead of Holidays
item.description: USPS has been picking up the slack and handling an average of 6 million extra packages per day.   Truth: "This year can't end fast enough," Jennifer Lemke, the clerk craft director at APWU Local 170 in Ohio, told the Washington Post.   At the same time, its workforce has shrunk due to Covid.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: News by the Numbers: Vaccines, ICU Capacity, Consumer Confidence
item.description: 88.6: The December reading of U.S. consumer confidence, which fell sharply from November.   Covid patients are straining healthcare systems across the country, and almost one-fifth of hospitals with ICUs have filled 95% of beds. In the U.S., we're at 614k and counting.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Christmas Tree Supply Run Short During Pandemic
item.description: Christmas tree grower associations have reported that earlier purchases and increased sales this year are sapping inventory (the National Christmas Tree Association says it's not a shortage, just a tight supply).   One explanation: the recession But not the one fresh on your mind.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Should Apple Make Cars?
item.description: The bulls argue that while auto manufacturing takes a lot of cash, Apple is the rare company that has... Also, Apple investors are used to eye-popping growth—to keep its stock price on a roll, Apple needs to pursue new markets.   Tesla CEO Elon Musk seems to be gearing up for a fight.   Zoom out: While we don't have a final verdict on the Apple car, we know it would be a challenge to Tesla.   Root suggested it would be wiser for Apple to pursue the route Alphabet's Waymo has taken: developing self-driving tech to sell to automakers.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Second Stimulus Package: What You May Have Missed
item.description: A provision making illegal streaming a felony A tax break for racehorse owners  $2 billion for the U.S. Space Force Permission to create two new Smithsonian museums  $35 million for abstinence-only sex education   Okay, now think of the absolute randomest thing that could be tucked into an economic stimulus bill.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Run Your Own Zoom Trivia Night: Edition No. 2
item.description: [Pause to read off answers and have a representative from each team announce the points they earned in Rounds 5+6.   Step 2: Right before you start asking questions, distribute blank Team Sheets to each team in their private group message. At this point, familiarize yourself with the questions below as well as the Answer Key. Also, think of a fun prize for the winning teams to create an extra competitive atmosphere.   Step 4: Ask the questions below. Ask the team to choose a team name and hype them up. Round 1: The parentals  How it works: Teams must identify the two parents of the following “children.”   Step 3: Get everyone on a Zoom or videoconference and explain the basic rules: Six rounds (this shouldn’t take much more than an hour).   Ask teams to write down the host cities of the Olympics (both winter and summer) from 1992–2028. At the end of each round, ask the group if they want any questions repeated.   U.S. national parks  Zodiac signs Seven dwarfs Sports at the Summer Olympics  Fellowship of the Ring members  Dow companies (not including a number) Cities home to an Ivy League college First name of Backstreet Boys band members [Pause to read off answers and have a representative from each team announce the points they earned in Rounds 3+4. Teams will grade themselves when answers are announced every two rounds.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The NBA Ditches the Bubble as It Kicks Off Its 2021 Season
item.description: The backstory: The NBA’s decision to resume the 2020 season in the now-famous bubble in Florida paid off—revenue dipped only 10% and the league recouped an estimated $1.5 billion.      Bottom line: The NBA knows it’s in for a rocky year.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Health Insurer Oscar Health Files To Go Public
item.description: Yesterday, health insurance company Oscar Health confidentially filed for an IPO.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: New Coronavirus Strain Spooks Stocks, Commodities
item.description: Zoom out: New virus strains are to be expected (that’s why you get different flu shots each year). The European Commission just needs to sign off now. Experts currently believe Pfizer’s and Moderna’s vaccines will tackle it just fine.     + While we’re here...
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Peloton Buys Precor for $420 Million
item.description: That could be a significant growth opportunity for Peloton when/if those spaces fill up again after the pandemic subsides.   Precor could also be Peloton’s ticket into the commercial side of fitness. of prime manufacturing space in the U.S., which should help Peloton speed up delivery of its bikes.   Precor has 625,000 sq.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Congress Passes $900B Stimulus Bill
item.description: The Payroll Protection Program will get another $285 billion. It’ll bring back extra federal unemployment benefits ($300/week) and one-time $600 payments for millions of Americans, but tucked into the $900 billion package are some big benefits for businesses, too. More than $35 billion will go to energy R&D and the extensions of tax credits for solar and wind projects. The bill has set aside $15 billion for the airline industry; $10 billion for highways; $16 billion for transit and city buses; $2 billion for airports; and $1 billion for Uncle Joe-beloved Amtrak.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Congress Passes $900B Stimulus Bill
item.description: The Payroll Protection Program will get another $285 billion. It’ll bring back extra federal unemployment benefits ($300/week) and one-time $600 payments for millions of Americans, but tucked into the $900 billion package are some big benefits for businesses, too. More than $35 billion will go to energy R&D and the extensions of tax credits for solar and wind projects. The bill has set aside $15 billion for the airline industry; $10 billion for highways; $16 billion for transit and city buses; $2 billion for airports; and $1 billion for Uncle Joe-beloved Amtrak.

item.title: Health Insurer Oscar Health Files To Go Public
item.description: Yesterday, Oscar Health, a health insurance company that insures normal people, not only Meryl Streep, confidentially filed for an IPO.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Peloton Buys Precor for $420 Million
item.description: of prime manufacturing space in the U.S., which should help Peloton speed up delivery of its bikes.   Precor could also be Peloton’s ticket into the commercial side of fitness.   Precor has 625,000 sq. Investors gave the transaction a high five.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The NBA Ditches the Bubble as It Kicks Off Its 2021 Season
item.description: The backstory: The NBA’s decision to move games to the now-famous bubble in Florida to resume the 2020 season paid off—revenue dipped only 10% and the league recouped an estimated $1.5 billion.      Bottom line: The NBA knows it’s in for a rocky year.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Christmas is here
item.description: The Brew’s schedule: We’ll be in your inbox every day this week except Christmas.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: SolarWinds Hack: What We Know Now
item.description: Quick review: SolarWinds is a company that provides cybersecurity services.   In the past few days, more details about the massive Russia-linked hack of IT management software company SolarWinds have tumbled out. The affected networks will remain compromised as investigators assess the fallout, which could take months or even longer.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Cyberpunk 2077: What Went Wrong
item.description: The backstory: First announced in 2012, Cyberpunk 2077 was the crown jewel of Polish game studio CD Projekt Red. It promised exceptional customization features and an expansive dystopian universe with none other than Keanu Reeves at the center.   Both Sony and Microsoft are offering full refunds for copies purchased through their online stores.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Congress Finally Agrees on a Follow-Up Stimulus Package
item.description: Added unemployment benefits of $300 per person  $300 billion for the Paycheck Protection Program, which supports small businesses  A $15 billion injection to help airlines rehire over 32,000 workers who were furloughed in October, plus more for airports and air travel-related industries.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Tesla Joins S&P 500, Capping Sensational Year for Elon Musk
item.description: Tesla is not an ordinary stock For one, it’s absolutely humongous. With a market capitalization of $659 billion, Tesla will be the largest company to ever enter the S&P 500. Looking ahead: Could Tesla stock become...   More than $4.5 trillion is managed by index funds that track the S&P 500.   Third, for many years Tesla wasn’t profitable. What does it mean for the stock market? Today, electric automaker Tesla will join the U.S. stock market’s equivalent of Top 40 radio: the S&P 500 index.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Finally: Congress Agrees on a Follow-Up Stimulus Package
item.description: Added unemployment benefits of $300 per worker  $300 billion for the Paycheck Protection Program, which supports small businesses  A $15 billion injection to help airlines rehire over 32,000 workers who were furloughed in October, plus more for airports and air travel-related industries.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Tesla Joins the S&P 500, Capping a Sensational Year for Elon Musk
item.description: could Tesla stock become... Tesla is not an ordinary stock For one, it’s absolutely humongous. With a market capitalization of $659 billion, Tesla will be the largest company to ever enter the S&P 500.   More than $4.5 trillion is managed by index funds that track the S&P 500. Today, electric automaker Tesla will join the U.S. stock market’s equivalent of Top 40 radio: the S&P 500 index. What does it mean for the stock market?   Second, the stock is extremely volatile, meaning it’s prone to dramatic daily swings based on company news that might not be a huge deal.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.description: Quick review: SolarWinds is a company that provides cybersecurity services.   In the past few days, more details about the massive Russia-linked hack of IT management software company SolarWinds have tumbled out. The affected networks will remain compromised as investigators assess the fallout, which could take months or even longer.

item.title: Christmas is here
item.description: The Brew’s schedule: We’ll be in your inbox every day this week except Christmas.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Morning Brew Readers Share Their Quarantine Dating Stories
item.description: Some made us laugh, some made us cry, and others made us go, “Hmm, didn’t know masks could be used for that.” And because we just met, neither one of us wanted to end the date because we had to pee. To spice things up I said my favorite drink was Mountain Dew... “Did a virtual date for the first time. The call ended about 5 minutes later when I told her I can't date a liar.” she didn't bat an eye and proceeded to tell me she doesn't really drink soda. For more pandemic dating stories, check out the Social Distance Project.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: OnlyFans Makes Money Moves Amid the Pandemic
item.description: Of that $400 million in revenue, OnlyFans will make $300 million in profit, per The Information.   Creators on OnlyFans will generate more than $2 billion in sales this year, Bloomberg reports.   Once known exclusively for NSFW content creators, OnlyFans has been flooded by celebrities who went looking for a new revenue stream when concerts, studio production, and other forms of live entertainment were put on pause.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Covid-19 Baby Bust: U.S. Could See 300k Fewer Births Next Year
item.description: Okay, maybe the pandemic and accompanying recession are a better explanation. The Covid-19 baby bust won't only “doesn't only depress overall productivity, but it also puts a burden on social insurance systems,” Brookings Senior Fellow Melissa Kearney told Business Casual. At the macro level, this could skew the future workforce toward older people.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Dating Apps See Increased Engagement But Struggle to Convert it to Dollars
item.description: Throughout the pandemic, dating app users starved of human interaction have been video chatting, swiping, and pickup-lining like they’re Tom Hanks in Castaway.   The top 20 dating apps have gained 1.5 million daily active users this year, according to Apptopia data from November.   OkCupid reported a 188% increase in coronavirus mentions on profiles between January and February.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Morning Brew/Harris Poll Finds Americans Split in Pandemic Dating Attitudes
item.description: So what does a pandemic date look like?   Bottom line: “The dating game in COVID is all screen and no scene,” said Harris Poll CEO John Gerzema. 59% of respondents say they will be dating less once the pandemic is over, but 41% say they will date more. “While 40% are using dating apps more, 44% have anxiety over lost time dating in real life.   We’re similarly polarized on the topic of dating FOMO.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Brew Crossword: Formula Fun
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Covid-19 Baby Bust: U.S. Could See Up to 500k Fewer Births Next Year
item.description: Other variables weighing on parents: Reduced access to reproductive services  Fears about coronavirus affecting a fetus  Being home with existing children 24/7 (sounds mean, but if we had to spend the pandemic with our 13yo selves...   Okay, maybe the pandemic and accompanying recession are a better explanation.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Morning Brew/Harris Poll Finds Americans Split in Pandemic Dating Attitudes
item.description: So what does a pandemic date look like?   Bottom line: “The dating game in COVID is all screen and no scene,” said Harris Poll CEO John Gerzema. Fifty-nine percent of respondents say they will be dating less once the pandemic is over, but 41% say they will date more. “While 40% are using dating apps more, 44% have anxiety over lost time dating in real life.   We’re similarly polarized on the topic of dating FOMO.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Dating Apps See Increased Engagement But Struggle to Convert it to Dollars
item.description: The top 20 dating apps have gained 1.5 million daily active users this year, according to Apptopia data from November. Users are active, active Video chatting on Bumble spiked 93% in the pandemic’s early days, while the average conversation length on Tinder rose 10%–30%.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Bitcoin Is All Grown Up
item.description: Accumulation is the name of the game Around 62% of bitcoin in circulation hasn’t changed hands in over a year, a sign that fewer people are actively trading bitcoin, and more are holding onto it (HODL, if you will).    Inexperienced investors getting burned by altcoins (aka cryptocurrencies that aren’t bitcoin) is a familiar story. That’s because bitcoin isn’t being used as an intermediary to move capital into other “shitcoins.”       Searches for keyword "Bitcoin" via Google Trends Zoom out: A look at Google search data indicates interest by individual investors is far lower than  it was in 2017.   Investors have wisened up on altcoins Rewind to 2017. And publicly traded companies like Square and MicroStrategy have moved portions of their cash reserves into bitcoin.   Startups like Ryze and Swan help users accumulate bitcoin at regular intervals regardless of price, a classic investing strategy known as dollar-cost averaging (DCA).   Institutional investors have entered the chat In 2017, JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon called bitcoin a fraud and a bubble: “It’s worse than tulip bulbs.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Mortgage Rates Hit 15th Record Low This Year
item.description: Compared to 2019, mortgage applications are up 26% and refinances 105%, per the Mortgage Bankers Association. FYI: Freddie Mac is a government-sponsored mortgage investor. But good luck getting your hands on cheap property: Surging home sales have squeezed supply and inflated prices.
item.author: Alex Hickey
